Situation1: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A long-time congregant requested a private meeting soon because of mounting family stress.
Story:
The factory floor buzzed with tension as I crouched beside the halted production unit, sweat beading on my brow. The supervisor hovered nearby, his voice tight: “We can’t afford more downtime. Please, find the fault quickly.” My hands moved over the tangled wires, searching for the elusive sensor error that had brought everything to a standstill. Every minute lost meant mounting costs and anxious faces watching me, expecting answers.

My phone vibrated in my pocket. It was a message from Brother Yusuf, a devoted member of my congregation. “Imam, I really need to talk. It’s urgent—my family is falling apart. Can you meet soon?” I could sense the desperation in his words, the kind of pain that needed more than a quick reply. As an imam, I was expected to be present, to listen, to offer comfort and guidance when my community needed me most.

I stared at the blinking lights on the machine, my mind torn. The factory needed me now, but so did Yusuf. Both roles demanded my full attention, and I felt the weight of their expectations pressing in, pulling me in opposite directions.
